abstract.text: Enable your node to respond to user input, like touches or mouse clicks.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: subclasses
in iOS and tvOS, and
in macOS, allowing nodes to respond to user interaction events such as touches and mouse movements.
There are two strategies you can adopt when supporting user interaction.
Enable user interaction on a single catch-all node, for example the scene, and calculate the child node or nodes that the user is interacting with by doing custom hit tests.
Enable user interaction on every node you want the user to interact with, and subclass them to implement their responder functions.

content.text: Enable User Interaction on All Nodes

inlineContent.text: Listing 3 shows an example of supporting user interaction on individual nodes in your scene. Instances of
are added as children of a standard scene and user interaction is handled by each independently.
In the case of overlapping nodes, only one will register a user interaction. For example, of two overlapping nodes, the one with the highest
receives the touch. For two nodes with an equal
, the last node in the parentâ€™s
array receives the touch.
Listing 3. A sprite node that responds to touches

inlineContent.text: Translucent nodesâ€“those with an
of less than
but greater than

to
to make it effectively transparent and yet still respond to touches or mouse movements, although giving it a color of

content.text: Review the Bounds of Node User Interaction

inlineContent.text: User interaction is based on the bounding box of the node. Sprite nodes containing textures with transparent areas or shape nodes with non-rectangular shapes will still report touches and mouse interactions even if the interaction is over a transparent part of their content.
If you build a composite node, the region that receives user interaction events is dependent on the node tree. Listing 4 shows the code used to create a subclassed
that renders six circular shape nodes forming a larger circle.
Listing 4. A composite node that responds to touches

code: // For macOS replace this method with `mouseDown(with:)`
override func touchesBegan(_ touches: Set<UITouch>, with event: UIEvent?) {

However, if you were to place an instance of
above another node using, for example, the code in Listing 5, only touches on its child nodes would be reported.
Listing 5. Placing a composite node over a background
In this case, only touches or mouse events over the red spots shown in the figure below will call
Nodes that have user interaction disabled will block touch and mouse events on nodes behind them where they overlap.

abstract.text: An abstract class that forms the basis of event and command processing in AppKit.
An abstract interface for responding to and handling events.
Tells this object that one or more new touches occurred in a view or window.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
The transparency value applied to the nodeâ€™s contents.
Returns the deepest visible descendant that intersects a point.
Returns a rectangle in the parentâ€™s coordinate system that contains the position and size of itself and all child nodes.
The focus behavior for a node.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the node receives touch events.
Returns an array of all visible descendants that intersect a point.
The height of the node relative to its parent.
An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.
Tells you when the scene is presented.
Define the appearance or layout of scene content.
